awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Telomerase Regulation in Deep Branching Eukaryotes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on telomerase, the  enzyme that is responsible for making telomeres, structures that protect the ends of all eukaryotic chromosomes, reminiscent of the hard ends of shoelaces. The genetic mechanism of telomere replication by telomerase is better studied in yeast and mammalian cells; as far from each other as those two organisms are, they in fact represent relatively recent branches of eukaryotic phylogeny. In contrast, in this study an ancient, deep branching lineage of eukaryotes, kinetoplastid protists will be examined. The organism of choice, Trypanosoma brucei, has telomerase with unique structural and functional properties, and result should indicate how this enzyme works. The project will encourage full participation from women and underrepresented minorities in science. Apart from training graduate and postdoctoral trainees, this project will also implement a three-year undergraduate program (BIOKEYS) in both PIs' laboratories; the major goal of this program will be to teach undergraduate researchers to value interdisciplinary sciences early in their research careers. In addition to gaining experience from designing experiments and problem solving using high-end technologies, students will be teaching and learning from each other as part of a research group.

Telomerase, a ribonucleoprotein enzyme, provides the major means for elongation of chromosome ends (telomeres), thus counteracting the loss of linear DNA ends in each cell cycle due to incomplete DNA replication by conventional DNA polymerases. Telomerase has two core components, the Telomerase Reverse Transcriptase (TERT) that catalyzes telomere elongation, and the telomerase RNA (TER), which provides a template for telomere DNA synthesis. The mechanisms of telomere elongation by telomerase are poorly understood in Trypanosoma brucei, a deep branching Kinetoplastid. Therefore, this project dissects structural, biochemical and genetic features of telomerase RNA in T. brucei to understand the mechanism of telomerase regulation in early eukaryotic species. The recent discovery of the T. brucei TER reveals novel features exclusive to deep branching eukaryotes, suggesting mechanistic differences in the process of telomere synthesis between T. brucei and higher eukaryotic organisms. Therefore, this project: (i) investigates telomerase RNA structure at a single nucleotide resolution using NMR and SHAPE chemistry, (ii) defines key TERT contact sites on TER that are essential for telomerase function in T. brucei using HITS-CLIP technology, and (iii) establishes the functional significance of TR domains by genetic manipulations and telomerase functional assays. Overall, this research will allow significant advances in understanding the mechanistic details of telomerase evolution in protists.

Award Title: Collaborative Research: Telomerase Regulation in Deep Branching Eukaryotes

Federal Award ID: 1764273

Principal Investigator (PI): Dr. Kausik Chakrabarti (UNC Charlotte)

 

In 2017, University of North Carolina at Charlotte received NSF funding for the NSF project award entitled: Collaborative Research: Telomerase Regulation in Deep Branching Eukaryotes. The aim of this project was to define unique structural and functional properties of telomerase ribonucleoprotein enzyme complex in the kinetoplastid parasite, Trypanosoma brucei.

 

Telomerase is a ribonucleoprotein (RNP) enzyme that promotes unlimited cell proliferation through the extension of protective telomere caps at the ends of linear chromosomes. It is minimally composed of a telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) and a telomerase RNA (TR) which includes an internal template that associates with the TERT to stimulate telomere elongation. This project studied the dynamics of the TR’s secondary structure in the context of Trypanosoma brucei, the deep branching protozoan parasite. The TR of T. brucei shares some common features and structural domains with other eukaryotes, however the genetic sequence is unique to each species. Unlike the other organisms, T. brucei has a dual-host life cycle: the mammalian phase (Bloodstream form) and the insect phase (Procyclic form). Utilizing novel high-throughput sequencing based RNA structure mapping technique, this NSF funded project deciphered the telomerase RNA (TR) structure of T. brucei in vivo and in catalytically active immunopurified telomerase complex in single-nucleotide resolution. Importantly, these studies revealed significant differences in the TR structure and TERT interactions between two distinct developmental stages in the parasite. In particular, these observed differences in TR folding at two distinct life stages suggested that RNA conformational changes are a key component of T. brucei telomere replication and development. Surprisingly, an array of Small Nucleolar RNA (snoRNA) binding proteins (snoRNPs) was identified in the proteome of T. brucei TERT complex and bind particularly to the novel C/D box domain of the TR, suggesting potential role of this structural domain in RNA maturation in T.brucei telomerase. Mutational analysis of the T.brucei RNA specific Template Boundary Element, Helix-IV and the novel C/D box resulted in reduced telomerase activity compared to WT, suggesting their important roles in T.brucei telomerase biology. Overall, this project revealed novel features exclusive to deep branching eukaryotes, suggesting mechanistic differences in the process of telomere synthesis between T. brucei and higher eukaryotic organisms.

 

The educational activities conducted during the project time period expanded access to high-impact research and STEM professional development opportunities for undergraduate students. Particularly, this project provided training opportunities to minority students and trainees from diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds via an innovative and collaborative undergraduate (REU) training program, termed ‘BIOKEYS’. This program allowed undergraduate students to develop high-end technical skills at an early stage of their career, particularly working on telomerase affinity purification, Immunopurification and profiling of RNA-protein complexes using Mass Spectrometry, RNA structure probing using SHAPE-Map technique and developing computational pipeline for RNA structure probing using SQL database system. Authentic research opportunities through BIOKEYS provided training opportunities to students from underrepresented minorities—Hispanics or Latinos, Blacks or African American students who participated in this research. Notably, this project supported women in science as majority of undergraduate students in BIOKEYS program were female. Also, graduate students who worked in this project developed their peer-mentoring skills by teaching high-school students from STEM field.  Thus, these women trainees served as peer-mentors and role models to the other undergraduate students in the laboratory or to school students. Together these efforts are expected to impact a large body of undergraduate and graduate students by promoting their research and scientific process skills, scientific identity and sense of belonging, and ability to successfully navigate post-college steps in their STEM career journeys. This project also allowed dissemination of knowledge from research discovery towards technological understanding and societal benefits. PI included the research and technological progresses made during the project period in his classroom teaching materials to provide up-to-date advances in telomerase and telomere research. The project generated new knowledge about telomerase biology in early, deep-branching eukaryotes, resulting in 5 peer-reviewed articles and 8 local, regional and national level conference presentations and symposiums.
